div.head: Introduction
div.p: The Neo-Latin play Iugurtha presented here was penned by the Tyrolean priest Joseph Resch (1716–1782). Originally from Hall in Tyrol, the author was prefect and teacher at the prince-bishop’s Gymnasium in Brixen (South Tyrol) for almost twenty years between 1742 and 1761. As part of this role he was heavily involved in the school theatre of this educational institution and wrote the dramas for the performances himself. In addition, the multifaceted scholar gained fame as an author of textbooks as well as theological, hagiographic and especially historiographic works.

The texts of twelve of Resch’s school dramas are preserved in handwritten form; in addition, three Latin meditation dramas (Meditationes Sacrae) composed for the student’s Congregation established by Resch at the Gymnasiun in Brixen survive. These plays are written in the tradition of the early modern school drama. In particular the influence of the Jesuit drama is visible. Like the Jesuits, Resch dramatized mostly heroic material that could be used to make a moral or religious statement. A special feature of Resch’s oeuvre, however, is the frequent treatment of local historical subjects in particular. Almost all of his plays are written in Latin, some with interludes in the local vernacular—this too corresponds to the practice of contemporary religious drama.

The tragedy Iugurtha is the oldest school drama by Joseph Resch known today. It was staged in the autumn of 1746, and like most of the author’s other surviving plays, it was performed as ludus autumnalis, i.e. as part of the festivities at the end of the school year. The play is composed entirely in Latin; its style and its motives are heavily influenced by the tragedies of Seneca the Younger, as is the conception of the play’s tyrannical main character.

div.head: Content
div.p: The drama takes place in the last phase of the Jugurthine War. The Romans have taken control of Numidia, only the city of Cirta is still in the hands of Jugurtha. While the Roman army waits at the gates of the besieged city for an order to attack, the officer Sulla tries to persuade Jugurtha’s son-in-law, Bocchus, to defect and betray Jugurtha. Meanwhile, the play’s main character—trusting in a misinterpreted dream—insists on defending the city by military means against the overwhelmingly powerful Romans. With inside help from Numider, a bribed Cirtian, the Roman soldiers finally succeed in taking the city. In the end, Jugurtha is lured into a trap by Sulla with Bocchus’ help and is thus captured.

div.head: Sources
div.p: In contrast to most of Resch’s other plays, no perioche has been preserved for Iugurtha. For this reason, we also lack information for the sources used by Resch. However, due to the close match in the portrayal of the plot, there is no doubt that Sallust’s Bellum Iugurthinum, especially chapters 106 to 114, was the most important source text for the play.

div.head: Tradition and editorial principles
div.p: The original manuscript, written for the first performance of the play in 1746, is located in the library of the Brixen diocesis seminary of the under the signature SEM F 22. The text was first edited in 2018 as part of the project “Brixner Schultheater: Edition und Übersetzung der neulateinischen Dramen von Joseph Resch”, based at the University of Innsbruck.

The editor’s intention was not to deliver a faithful reproduction of the original text, but rather to provide a readable and easy-to-use version of the text. To this end, the punctuation has been adapted to modern standards and accents have been removed. All abbreviations and ligatures have been resolved. Orthography and phonetics are based on modern editions of classical Latin texts: The frequent replacement of i by y has been reversed (e.g. sidus for sydus), as have non-classical diphthongs (e.g. felix instead of foelix). The distinction between vowel i and consonant j has similarly been reversed. Non-classical consonant doublings have been removed (e.g. belua for bellua). Initial ch and later aspirations have been eliminated (e.g. letum instead of lethum) and the lost interconsonant s has been restored (e.g. exstinxerat instead of extinxerat). Proper names and words at the beginning of sentences have been capitalised.
